My friend asked a member of staff to open the side fire exit door and I used the slope to get to the door. Once in it was all flat. The food was lovely and the staff were friendly and helpful. The bar in the next room sales great cocktails.

I would recommend trying to sit by the loos which are at the back if you use the outside entrance or at the front if you enter from inside the outlet village. This means you don‚Äôt have to travel through as many tight spaces to get to the toilet. Disabled toilet is decent.
Helped with heavy doors at entrance, good at pointing the way.

There is no disabled parking which I seen. So being a wheelchair user, I need room to get out and back into my car and have the confidence that no one will park next to me to obstruct me getting back into my car. I parked down at the main car park and there is no drop curd to get up onto the pavement. They do have a very small movable ramp to get up onto the pavement but caution is advised as someone could easily tip out of their chair when using it.
Loo accessible (unisex Radar key) good space for carer to assist. Clean, grab rails and easy to find. Monitored by security so only used by those meant to use it!
excellent access for people with disabilities, lifts for wheelchair access to the post office.
There is lift and quite a lot of seating like chairs and sofas.

Room was very small, asked for bed to be raised for hoist access, which it was but the bed was left in the middle of the room, so no room to get passed. Thick carpet in room made pushing hoist extremely difficult.

There is one and it's big enough with handrails but you need to use a radar key, which they have behind the bar if you don't have one. I didn't check it this time but the lock was broken last  summer for some time.

I did not have reason to speak with staff, but they are easily seen around the place and I felt I could have asked for their help if I needed it.
There are staffed desks at each of the entrances.
The museum was quite busy, with a mixture of visitors including families and school groups, everyone seemed to be welcomed.
Good Lothian Bus links with stops on Broughton Street. Some on street parking, but not guaranteed.

Several steps to main entrance, wheelchair access is along the side of the building and up a ramp. This door is a fire door and has to be opened from inside. My friend had to leave me in the  wind & rain and go back around the building to main entrance to gain access. The surface outside to the ramp looks as though it would be quite slippy underfoot when wet.There is a lift to upper floors. Plenty of seating for a rest, but quite a long corridor from accessible entrance to public area

Check in was a wee bit slow due to  ‚Äòthe system‚Äô being down and things had to be done manually.  Key cars allocated, we headed to our rooms.  The wheelchair room was fairly close to reception but in order to get to my room I had to go along one long corridor and then along another of similar length. I have to say by the time I  got to my room I was completely shattered.
Once in the room, it was massive!.  A large double bed and another single away in the corner of the room beside a desk and sofa.  The hairdryer was tucked away under the kettle with tea and coffee.  Typical open wardrobe (I can never get the hangers back on using one hand), shelves and power points, althought there wasn‚Äôt any beside the bed or even USB charge points such as in a Hoiliday  Express. Just a personal thing, but I did find the bed rather soft and low down.  I suppose not having a grab rail (nor my ‚ÄòBetter half‚Äô) I did find it a bit difficult getting out of bed in the morning

We didn't use the car park but did use the transport to the hotel which was first class. The return trip to the airport they didn't send a wheelchair accessible van so we had an hour wait. When we did get the van it was first class.
The toilets were used for both disabled & baby change, This meant that the bins were overflowing with nappy sacks as no one had cleaned them.
On Victoria Street which is not ideal for parking! Best bet is getting a bus to George IV bridge.
1 was very nice and helped however he could.  The other kept insisting we were disabled and should be sat in our wheelchairs as only paid for 1 seat
Fantastic. Really helpful onboard and off. Explain how ticketing works clearly and you can hear them offering help to everyone on board for whatever reason.

There are very few Disabled parking bays for such a new building which is very disappointing.
There is a vast car park with lots of parking space for abled bodied people.
There is no public transport to the Garden Centre and it is a good 30 minute walk from the bus stop to the actual venue

Access was pretty good as the doors were wide enough to easily wheel in and one set were automated with push button pads. Once inside there was ample space to get around and see most things. There was a mezzanine level displaying bicycles - this wasn't accessible.

Probably the last store of its kind in Scotland even though it‚Äôs not independent. All the Fraser stores carry pretty much the same stock, but this is the flagship store in Scotland, the customer service still has a bygone era feel to it especially among the older, experienced staff. There are more entrance and exit doors than most other Department Stores of which 4 double sets are power assisted and once in the Store, ample ramps and lifts throughout. As said earlier, being the flagship, we can only get particular products that we like here, one Edinburgh Store has closed followed by what used be Jenner‚Äôs in Edinburgh at a later date. The Hermes boutique shop offers a range of unique Hermes products and to accompany it, the service to match. The staff cannot do enough to assist with a patience to match. They also have the awareness and the observation to recognise and be alert to offer support.
I used the toilet at the pier there is one at the entrance to the pier and one in the Terrace Bar. Adequate for my scooter but not ultra modern.
There was a disabled toilet next to the main car park, although this was an outdoor toilet. There was also an indoor toilet available in the main building.
No steps entrance door wide enough and level. Soft play and cafe on one level.

The staff were as helpful and as patient as they could be but the fact remains there is NO LIFT to the stalls. I was told this is because it is a listed building and therefore not allowed to install one.
Wheelchair accessible,  all on the flat. Lacking disabled toilets though.  Drink cheap! Large wheelchair friendly function room
City Centre location, on street parking fairly close.  Didn't use transport on this occasion.
Helpful staff.
All the staff are great. There are plenty of staff who are all clearly made out by their distinctive uniforms. Also they are only too happy to help you out.
the staff were very well informed about access and explained which paths might not be suitable for my chair.
Disabled parking very limited, but public transport is excellent and highly accessible.

Overall Nuffield health Milngavie is very accommodating to people with disabilities through implementing a wheelchair lift and disabled parking. This creates a positive atmosphere for visitors who require this service.
The carpark has amply disabled parking
There is a dedicated blue badge parking space right beside the door. Blakeney is right by the sea in rural Norfolk so public transport is a lot trickier!
A good height with foldable rails to either side.
The parking is near the ramp to get into the chalet
East to find, wide door, I didn't notice anything else which makes it particularly suited to a disabled user.
Limited parking but accessible buses stop very close by.
Didn't have much contact with staff but spoke to someone twice who was polite and friendly.
As it's in the West End, driving is a bit of a non starter. Nearest stepfree tube is quite a way. We walked/wheeled from Waterloo which was a good 25 minutes.
All staff I encountered were keen to be helpful. Someone should tell them that it's OK to smile occasionally - they were needlessly severe and humourless, and occasionally a tiny bit officious.

There is a step into the caf√©. They have an extravagantly long folding metal ramp which they can deploy whenever you need it, and because it's so long you get a lovely smooth gentle ride up to the entrance. Some of the waiters and waitresses don't know about the existence of this ramp (the manager hasn't briefed them properly) so if you ask and you're told "We don't have a ramp", don't believe them!

The welcome from the staff as second to none. As it's a family run farm shop, everyone coming in and leaving the shop while I was there were treated like family too. There was a lovely atmosphere in the store.

Savignypl. 11, 10623 Berlin, Germany, 
There are  about 10 restaurants in this lovely little square, after visiting them all to try and get dinner, I found this was the only one with a disable toilet. It is a great busy place about a miles walk (or wheel) from the zoo, great to eat out of an evening and they do great Vietnamese food
Limited on street parking. Adjacent to the station and the Airlink bus services.
Step-free entry into the bookshop, but I was unable to get at most of the bookshelves. Not recommended for wheelchair users.

Absolutely fantastic service, I rented an electric wheelchair to avoid taking mine abroad in case the airline damaged it. The chair I was provided with was fantastic for the terrain and enabled me to go wherever I wanted independently. The gentleman Frederico met me at the hotel lobby at the time arranged and as he was running late we left the chair in the lobby with reception for collection. I am quite small and of course rental chairs are generally larger than ones I require but we found it very easy to use pillows and my own cushions from my manual wheelchair to make it suitable - however it maybe necessary that certain extra cushions are taken to make the chairs fit every individual. The chair we hired was a Terra which I'd not heard of before but was definitely the best electric wheelchair I've hired abroad. It had a great range, managed small kerbs and bumps with ease, had a small wheelbase with great turning circle and fitted on all the buses easily. It definitely made the holiday a holiday for all. I'd definitely recommend Amigo 24 for any electric wheelchair hire in the future if we end up in an area that they operate in. They also hire out manual wheelchairs and mobility scooters as well as other mobility and disability aids which can be incredibly handy and helpful whilst away on holiday.

In my room I had an accessible toilet with a single grab rail and in the ground floor communal area there was also an accessible public toilet. It was signposted from reception. There was a manual door into the sink area which had wheelchair space below. Then there was a second manual door into the spacious toilet area. There was a single grab rail, see photos. There was no emergency cord and the door was unlocked/ didn‚Äôt require a special key to open it. The toilet was very clean.

Parking is probably one of the weak spots as it is not easy to park in the area. That said, it is true of so many places in the city during the festivals. Bus travel was easier with Princes Street only a short five minute walk away.
Perfectly OK, told us where the lift was, staff appeared when needed.
We were able to get the information we wanted from the website prior to visiting. We ordered tickets by post. Once in town the service was very accessible for us and easy use as a powerchair user.
staf were very helpful & friendly.
There are 2 ramps giving access to clubhouse
The toilet facilities are accessible for wheelchair users
The parking is good but the park gets busy. Edgebaston cricket ground is just over the road so avoid match das as parking gets full.
Easy to park and good range of level access shops but no public toilets.
Car parking space right outside the door.

The Brooks Hotel was not what I expected although I‚Äôm not sure what that was. Going in the door the magic began to unfold as it was a cross between Alice in Wonderland and Harry Potter. Every corner revealed something different and exciting.

Our tour guide Laura was lovely, she had been out the night before scouting the location and making sure that all the places she wanted to show us were accessible. She was friendly, funny and easy to chat to. She made sure that everyone in the group was comfortable with the pace and volume of the tour and ensured that we were all enjoying ourselves. I would recommend this tour wholeheartedly.

The nearest tube station South Kensington is not step free. Although the Piccadilly, District and Circle line stop there all the platforms involve steps to the ticket office hall level and then further steps to street level. This is really disappointing. There are a number of buses that stop outside or near to the V and A. I would suggest picking up bus no 14 from Green Park which is an step free station.
There are many toilet facilities throughout the venue that are all fully accessible.
The staff were increadibly kind and caring. We were looked after from the security men to the customer shop to the people in the shop. Every was really kind.

Although it is a 300-year old coaching inn, the owners have tried hard to make access as good as it can possibly be. The level access entrance porch door has a clearance of 26 inches, then a sharp left turn leading into the reception area. On our visit, the wheelchair user was in a Sunrise Quickie 6-wheel and she is a very experienced driver. She managed with relative ease, but anyone with a larger manual or powered wheelchair might struggle to manoeuvre. Previous diners using a wheelchair have opted to phone ahead to check access and one keen diner even visited ahead of booking to make sure she wasn't disappointed. Staff are more than happy to discuss your access needs in advance to ensure you have a positive experience. 

The reception/ bar and restaurant are on ground floor level and have level access throughout. There are no doors between each of the 3 dining areas. The reception area has comfy chairs and fixed, padded, bench-type seating, all without arms. A seat with arms can be made available and all tables and chairs in this area can be moved around if required. The reception/ bar area has wooden flooring and there is short pile carpet in the dining rooms. Diners can enjoy aperitifs and canap√©s in comfort whilst choosing from the menu and are then escorted to their table once their meal is ready. All dietary requirements can be catered for with prior notice.

Lighting throughout the building is natural daylight. There are wall lights, and candles on tables throughout the restaurant. For guests staying in The Residence, there is good lighting throughout the car park and between the bedrooms and the restaurant. There is a monobloc path from The Residence to the restaurant with a slight gradual slope from the Residence. 

There is a manual, double glass door at the entrance to The Residence, with a very small raised lip. A member of staff is normally on duty at reception between 8.30am and 8pm to assist if required. There are eight suites in The Residence, seven of which are split level with bedroom and bathroom on the lower floor plus a separate living room on the upstairs mezzanine level. The corridor and rooms are carpeted.  There is also a fire door half way along the corridor, which shortens the distance from The Residence to the car park and the restaurant. At the far end of the corridor, there is one level, designated accessible room with lots of space to move around, plus a luxurious, en suite wet-room. There is a small, raised lip of 1.5 cm to shower entry. There are lever taps on the washbasin and bath, with horizontal and vertical, colour-contrasted grab rails around the shower. The floor is tiled and there are down-lights throughout bathroom. All bedroom furniture can be moved to suit guests' needs. The wardrobe has a pull-down rail for easy access.
The accessible loo was easy to find, very spacious and well-facilitated and clean.

For a busy, modern day airport terminal what you would and should expect, all areas fully accessible, ample seating with refreshment and food outlets.
The Fullers London Pride outlet offered BSL and large Print assistance.
The staff are friendly and helpful but on busy days it can be a long wait till order taken.
One member of staff was friendly and helpful and directed me to the toilets.
The venue has one or two disabled parking spaces, there are good bus links and on street parking nearby.
Private car park at back of hotel with disabled access to reception
Friendly, local staff. Never had anyone question me for not looking disabled when I have purchased a disabled ticket or requested a seat reservation.

Some treatment rooms not accessible for wheelchairs. Waiting area has nowhere to 'park' so you are not in the way of other patients. 'Disabled' toilet cannot accommodate a chair, no grab rail on one side of toiletand door will not close with a self propelling standard sized chair inside
There is disabled access, lifts, several accessible toilets, induction loops, large print maps, wheelchair hire and registered assistance dogs are permitted
Was at Newcastle at weekend and found building called the Baltic. Just wonderful things going on....wonderful views of all the bridges.
Staff are helpful and friendly.
Access around the whole apartment building where we went was 1st class.

The cafe is up on the old platform in the old waiting room. It‚Äôs a steep ramp to get up on to the platform. The entry to the cafe is step free at the front but has a step down to exit at the back. You can also get to the seating areas by coming back out the front and round the side. There is a marquee at platform level with seating in or down the ramp there is a level floor hexagonal covered seating area or a wooden area but this has a step.
Ramp,entrance and toilet facilities good but no access to upstairs

The Regal is a Wetherspoons pub and club just outside of the centre of town. This venue is completely accessible for a wheelchair user, however it is let down by how crowded it can get on a Friday and Saturday night.
King's Cross underground station serves both King's Cross and St Pancras International railway stations. There are several bus routes that stop outside.
Excellent and very friendly! They make sure the facilities are extremely clean.
The access is very good indeed for all types of chairs and scooter as well although. You have to leave the scooter downstairs
Very friendly and helpful. Asked if I needed and assistance, showed me to the changing room to try my purchase.
Disabled parking available that is free of charge.
Very good , wheelchair friendly
The toilets were of a high standard. They were spacious, clean and there was plenty of them. There was a disabled toilet which had plenty of room and grab rails included.

There are wide automatic doors on entrance to the foyer of the theatre and a low counter at the box office till. A lift can take customers to the studio, main house, dress circle and theatre bars. Wheelchair spaces are available in the theatre stalls and circles if pre-booked. Assistance dogs are allowed in all parts of the theatre. For hearing impaired individuals, a loop system is available from the box office counter. Brochures are also available in large print and audio transcribed formats. There are BSL performances on specific showings as well as audio described performances. Staff also explained that they provided easy read maps of the theatre layout to individuals to reassure them of the place before they entered. Similarly, there are also touch tours at the theatre, where individuals familiarise themselves with the set, props and costumes before the performance.
Level access in the church. The only challenge is getting up the short hill to get in (and cobbles at the entrance to the path)

For me the access was great. I only awarded three stars as it would have been great to see them have a wheelchair accessible 'car' on the train. I didn't manage to see or find one. I particularly liked the audio commentary as it brought things alive for me as I may not have known what I was looking at otherwise!
No step at door, inside it's a bit tight but I am sure they would serve you outside
Car parking is behind the venue, buses pass nearby and taxis can also stop nearby. It is level access from these drop off points into the venue.

Superb accessible toilet just of the main cafe area. Good wide door, bright and light, with plenty of space to manoeuvre. Easily room for a carer / PA if required. Grab rails and fittings all at good height and easy to access.
All very friendly  and helpful

There is space to temporarily park outside the restaurant however for a longer-stay disabled parking bay, they are round the corner at a further distance. There is flat ground throughout the town centre if you were to access the restaurant from already being in the town. There are no bus stops immediately by the restaurant, however there are within a 5-10 minute walk.

The red cord in the disabled toilet was tucked behind a pipe and had been cut short by approximately one metre.

I untucked it to let it hang before attaching a Euan's Guide Card.
The buses to downtown Disney springs are fully accessible and everything is flat and accessible.  The car park is a long way from the rainforest cafe though so I wouldn't recommend driving

As always I check out the disabled loos, most of them didnt even have an emergency cord, one I couldnt even get my wheelchair in, another had more spiders in than I was willing to sit around and count,  One of the 'new loos' which had one an award, had the red cord so tight in the corner behind the loo that it would be impossible to get to if you fell,  Most of the attractions although say they are accessible are not truly if you cannot walk, on the 'Thomas' Train I had to wait until everyone was on so the train could pull forward as the barrier was in the way and couldnt turn my wheelchair to get up the ramp. on the Drayton Manor train I could get on fine, but there was a step that made it near impossible to get off again the guard had to push my electric chair.  Most rides unless u can walk are not accesible I am fortunate that I can partly weight bare, or I would have been excluded from even more rides.

Chose to go to Preston Park and Museum on a rainy day with grandkids.  Park is lovely for the kids, but the museum was a lovely surprise.  Easy access, nice wide spaces inside for our boot scooter to navigate around, lift to the relevant floors.  Displays inside small but cover a lot of things, we especially like the 'olden day's (60s/70s etc) bit upstairs of how we used to live. Also outside is a small street set up in that 'olden day' style.  Street was partly cobbled but also partly paved so again no problems for the scooter.  Nice cafe there too but we didn't use that.
The car park is opposite the restaurant and you have to cross a busy road.  There are traffic lights 200 metres and we were lucky because cars were stopped for the red lights and let us through.
Not many disabled spaces. Car park quite bumpy to get over on wheelchair wheels.

The reason for the half star is that once you are in it's flat, but that's where it ends. It had a tall step to bump Pauls wheelchair up and an extremely heavy door, had we known there were no disabled toilets we wouldn't of bothered. Once inside they had booths but only for people who were eating so, as we were only in for a pint, we were directed over to a high table with high chairs. So we sat at completely different levels while we had our pint.
There are steps leading to the front entrance however there is a wheelchair accessible entrance with push buttons to open the doors around the side of the venue.

There is a ramp between car park and the hotels reception, it's bar and restaurant. There is a toilet for disabled in the corridor between the three.  The is a lift to rooms on the first floor.  There is a fan in the room and it's needed - it was the hottest day of the year and the room was like a sauna.

The disabled facilities were clearly outlined in the brochure and included information about wheelchairs, hearing assistance, toilets, parking, assistance dogs, ear defenders, an easy read guide to visiting the festival, an easy read guide to the programme, additional needs badges and volunteer escorts.  Their brochure was also available in large print, braille, audio CD and MP3 format.  They provided details of how to contact them should help with access be required.  We used these contact details for help with our parking problems and this help was indeed provided.

The large cafe was accessible for our wheelchair users and we were able to pull tables together so that we could all sit together and watch all the activity. The food available would not necessarily have been ideal for our people with disabilities but we had brought their own food with us anyway.
The staff in the Sea Life Centre was helpful and gentle. At the Coffee Bar the staff was very nice.

Great little gym and nice libary - great if you just want to sit on a comfy seat and relax while reading a book. However, I mostly use the venue for the gym. As a disabled man, I feel keeping my fitness to a high level is vital so, I attend the gym in Fochabers multiple times a week. However, I feel that it is only a suitable gym for you if like myself, you have the ability to come out of your wheelchair and transfer onto the equipment.

There is no parking at the station, unless you don't mind parking your car on the streets next to it. There is a bus stop directly infront of the stations main entrance. There is also a taxi rank outside main entrance, where you can either get dropped off or if you need a taxi, there is always taxis waiting outside.

Entrance straight off pavement.  Very slight lip but the door was wide enough for my wheelchair but would not suit an electric chair.  By booking early the carer could alert the waiter who opened an inner door.

There is a good (free) car park with some designated accessible places.  This place is really wheelchair friendly - the paths were all accessible & I had no trouble getting round the venue.  
Had a nice sandwich & a pot of tea in the cafe.
The accessible toilet at the cafe had plenty of room, grab rails etc.

Ask to drive back and park right at the museum for best wheelchair access. There are car parks, but they are far away and a very steep incline so best to park right at the museum in  back parking lot.
It was immediately obvious that the organisers had considered accessibility and gone to great lengths to welcome disabled visitors.
London Luton Airport is located north of central London. It is a smaller airport than Heathrow or Gatwick and is served by several airlines and offers flights to worldwide locations.
I only interacted with the person serving at the counter, who was very friendly. The caf√© offers self service.

The whole experience of our week in The Yorkshire Dales has been excellent, a great part of this was because staying at The Dairy allowed my husband to be independent and stress free, not things that can often be guaranteed when away from home, because of different levels of accessibility in accommodation.
We took my husbands mobility  scooter as well as his wheelchair. There is plenty of all around the cottage for turning a wheelchair and the scooter was parked in the hallway next to a wall socket.
This exceptional cottage is not only completely accessible, but is also beautiful, luxurious and comfortable.
We have already booked another holiday at The Dairy.

3 Lifts operated with Room Card

Accessible ramp into the hotel
Wheelchair accessible, pleasant atmosphere and good food.

The countryside around here is a little hilly, rising up to 450 feet, it‚Äôs good grazing and dairy farmland, lots of trees but no large woodland as such, but a pleasure to drive along. This is a small old fashioned canal pub, close to the junction of the Grand Union canal with the Stratford and Avon canal. The canal itself reached here in 1815, and it stands next to bridge 65. The canal itself is in a very attractive area, with lots of greenery, and inviting (photo 1). It is not far from Lapworth, on the B4493, and stands next to bridge 65. We mention this simply because there is an interesting walk for the able bodied, perhaps you may have children, or your little dog needs to find a wee place, but a short circular walk can be taken from here. First of all be careful crossing the B4439 as you need to get to the other side of the bridge ahead, then there are steps that will take you down onto the towpath, then walk away from the pub, with the canal now on your left, and take the short walk to the junction of the Grand Union canal with the branch canal known as the Lapworth link,   I believe this was opened in 1995, and going along this stretch of canal will take you round to meet the junction with the Stratford and Avon canal. You can then continue along that towpath and return to B4439 to turn right and return to The Navigation, but again be careful if you have children with you. If you the disabled person wants to see this connection of canals, then you need to drive out of car park area, and turn right on B4439 and go over the little canal bridge, then just a few yards later, turn left on Brome Hall lane, and drive past the few houses to a small parking area by the waterworks buildings, and to your left is a very small car parking area on dirt. Take the path leading down to towpath, and you can enjoy the views of the canal from there. Notice the Barrel roofed cottage by junction of the Lapworth link, most unusual. It‚Äôs a nice little area around these canals, but you really need a dry day, as it‚Äôs all dirt track, and may be impossible for you to get round to the actual junction itself, but you may wish to give it a try.
So, what do we feel about ‚ÄúThe Navigation‚Äù 
First of all make sure you have entered the Sat NAV directions for this pub, as there are three Navigation pubs in the vicinity, so enter B94 6NA for directions. We used this pub as part of our canal trip, and we will give you details on this trip later on with a fresh review of our historic canal trip.
The Navigation is in a beautiful setting alongside the Grand Union canal, and as we approached this small pub it had an appealing look about it.The car park was of a reasonable size, with easy access to the pub, simply going round the side of it into the delightful garden area, where we sat looking at the canal views with weeping willow trees, an idyllic spot for relaxing. A path takes you to the area under a canopy, (photo 3) and as it was very hot it gave plenty of shade to allow us to enjoy the surroundings. To get to the bar ready to order our drinks was easy enough, all on the level and through the little door (photo 4) then up to the bar, still all on the level.
It‚Äôs just a basic bar, nothing fancy, (photo 5) but a reasonable choice of drinks. You ride over a stone flagged floor, (photo 6)  so it was easy to get wheelchair along. There is a big log burner which we imagine in the winter when lit, would be very warm and welcoming.
Outside again, when you go through the canopy, there is a grassy area with tables and chairs (photo 7) and from here you can get unto the towpath to look over canal, but for walking you would need to get to the other side for the 
towpath. 
We enjoyed our short visit, very pleasant on this nice warm day, and enjoyed our drinks.  (photo 8). It serves a pint unique to the pub, Lapworth Gold, brewed in Coventry. 
We will say this though, that it was very pleasant sitting outdoors, rather than inside, which we feel is just a very basic pub, and it looks better from the road than indoors (photo 9). 
Our final thoughts. 
We chose this pub because of the historic Lapworth link, it‚Äôs not often you will find a circular walk between two different canals, so although The Navigation didn‚Äôt inspire us it was interesting enough a short break. We did not need toilets, so failed to report for you, but we cannot imagine a separate disabled toilet here, it‚Äôs not a big enough pub. For a short visit as you tour around, we feel you may manage this little pub and think we can recommend a visit for you.

The V and A has two step free entrances in Cromwell Road and Exhibition Road. I entered from Cromwell Road and there is a gradual slope as well as steps to the entrance. There was a revolving door and an accessible entrance next to it. When I arrived I got  manual wheelchair from a number which are near to the entrance. 
On my visit I stayed on the ground floor visiting the Frida Kahlo exhibition and restaurant. The entire route was step free. Getting to the exhibition involved going through the gift shop, the aisles were wide enough but it was busy. 
The Frida Kahlo exhibition was very popular and sold out on the day we visited. The exhibition focuses on her as a person and her image with a collection of personal artefacts and clothing. There is only a small display of her art work.
We had timed admission and there was no queue when we arrived. The exhibition was laid out in a series of rooms. The first was a long, straight corridor with paintings and photographs on both sides of the walls. The exhibits were at standing height but the labels were at a lower level which was perfect for me in a wheelchair. The other rooms had items on the walls plus display cabinets which were at wheelchair user height. I'm glad I used a wheelchair to get around as there was no fixed seating inside the exhibition.
Frida Kahlo was a disabled artist and one of the rooms focuses on her health and disability. On display is her prosthetic leg, decorated corsets which she wore after her operations and an assortment of medication. There are several photos that includes Frida's wheelchair. Interestingly when I was in this room people were very aware of my wheelchair and proactive about moving to let me see the exhibits, while in the other rooms both before and after I was often invisible. 
At the exit there are manual doors but a member of the public was there and opened the door for me.
Exiting via the gift shop there were two unmarked slopes, both of which caught me by surprise and I nearly needed up rolling into members of the public. 
The caf√© is self service with free standing tables and chairs. It was busy when we visited.
Has fully accessible disabled toilets.

The venue is level from the door in there is a large lift located just in front of the door if you want to go upstairs .  We did not use this area during this visit. 
There was room to move around in wheelchair to access area we wanted to go during our visit .

Disabeld access is good overall with ramps up to the main doors. However, I was surprised to find that the main doors had automatic door opening buttons but when I pressed these they did not work. Instead the automatic doors had been replaced with  standard manual doors with quite strong return arms on them, not easy when your in a wheelchair. This said I found the rest of the museum was widely accessible and managed to get to every one of the exhibits that I wanted to see.
There are buses & taxi ranks nearby, but accessible tube stations are lacking.
Generally disabled access is very good. Automated doors for wheelchair access. Great toilets. Very helpful staff.
Good effort with the toilets, could be a little cleaner.

Access in and around the building:

The building has a prominent entrance. The reception was bright and light with good signage. There was a hearing loop which was indicated by a prominent sign.

The lift had good contrasting controls and braille buttons. The doors to the bedrooms had good signage.

Access in the accessible bedrooms and bathrooms:

The accessible bedrooms were bright and spacious. The bathrooms were well lit. The rooms had a large button telephone.

The fire alarms in the rooms had the usual audio sounder but were also equipped with flashing lights. Vibrating alters for pillow were also available for hearing impaired guests.

Access in the dining area:

The dining area was large and well laid out.

Access to other facilities:

The hotel also had a bar and lounge area.

Some of our group arrived by car and were able to park adjacent to the building in the accessible parking bays. I and my companion arrived by Tram which was super accessible for me as a powerchair user.
Fantastic Changing Places Facility.  You need to ask for the code to get in, but it‚Äôs beautifully clean and well equipped.
There is a big step at the entrance. The shop has no wheelchair ramp. I was unable to get inside. Zero stars.

We visited Chester's Fort because it is an English Heritage site and we are members. With hindsight, some of the other Hadrian's Wall attractions are probably better for wheelchair access. We had a lovely visit but I was very limited in what I could access.
Brilliant, absolutely accessible and friendly
Staff were very friendly and welcoming.
Parking is next to the house with tiled surface all the way to the front door.

There is a level access door but this is usually locked so bring a friend. The food was delicious and this warm, dog friendly pub has a good atmosphere and lovely staff.

I did not explore whether there is an accessible toilet on my visit so please take this into account.

From the front it looks really small, but there's a big space around the back, where the drinking water is also kept. Though there's two steps down to that area. You can sit outside and a bit instead the building that is all on one level (though everywhere is roofed!). 
Wide spaces between tables.
Difficult for disabled people due to the sheer numbers of people congregated at the entrance to Edinburgh Castle, then the rush once we were let in.

The Beacon shopping centre houses Eastbourne‚Äôs largest collection of retail outlets under one roof. With an integral multi-storey car park the Beacon has three floors of shops, cafes, restaurants and a multiplex cinema all providing level access for the less able. Shopmobility is a mobility scooter, powerchair and class 1 wheelchair hire facility immediately outside the rear entrance at the eastern end of the centre and alongside the centrally situated accessible toilets is a Changing Place toilet facility.
Fantastic hosts and staff - nothing is too much trouble.
All the staff we met were very helpful!

We researched the place before our visit to ensure there was wheelchair  Access.  There is ample car parking for a fee.  There is a map illustrating different routes around the park but no actual markers along the paths.   The views and trees are stunning but the paths are gravelled and there are plenty  of undulations not ideal for a chaired person.  It was hard work wheeling and pushing.  We prefer nearby Bradgate Park with its tarmac pathways .
A small ramp at the entrance but otherwise fully accessible
Opposite the shop, well equipped, spacious.
Nearby parking.
The main theatre is fully accessible, with a lift to the upper floor - and staff will take out seat(s) downstairs if required.
You would need to drive as quite a remote area, no direct public transport.
Although rushed  off their feet, staff did their best to make our evening enjoyable..  Most had good English and helped with seats etc.
There are no steps throughout the whole park, all the ground was even and if you needed any help at any point you know there is plenty of staff around.
Helpful staff. First front desk waitron did not know the accessible entrance information but called over another staff member who was very helpful.
There are 3 disabled bays (free) to the side of the venue and a paid, covered, parking facility in the same location.
If you want to help or even if your starting up a Vouluntry group they can help
Caring and thoughtful, all very helpful without being over the top - all you would wish.
The Main Bedroom with en-suite wet-room (probably the best I can recall, always hot water, surfaces to accommodate toiletries etc. (a major fault I find in holiday wet rooms)
There is a single width lift ....no use for large motorised chairs or scooters
Apart from checking tickets I didn't interact with the staff. There was no interval for the performance.

Beautiful forest scenery takes you to the starting point, sometimes along busy roads, but it‚Äôs also quiet on some, and you cannot miss the sign to say you have arrived.
There are three disabled bays available just yards after arriving, but if full, the main free car park is just a few more yards away.
No hoist, standard disabled loo but you'll have to fight the healthies for the loo at break time as they don't want to wait for the normal toilets
The centre itself is a bit off the beaten track, so a walk if arriving by foot.  However there is a large car park with plenty of disabled bays available.
Appalling: broken seat, red cord only reaching part way to the ground and no flush arm visible.

There are 4 Christmas Markets in Edinburgh in 4 locations pretty much within what‚Äôs known as ‚Äò the square mile ‚Äò. They are all varied but based on the same Christmas theme, this site is West George Street from. Castle Street, westwards to Charlotte Square, where both sides of the road have been pedestrianised, no parking or bus facilities in this area though you are surrounded by nearby vehicular Access. This is dominated by a light show which is at roof top height and a also at foot andStreet level. Whilst there are some retail stalls, the main focus is on the bars, restaurants and clubs who have outdoor areas in the pedestrianised area. There are craft, jewellery, art and written goods available with winter clothing.  There is good temporary flooring in place rather than uneven, cracked paving and pot holes, but it can  be slippery in the wet. There is ample access for chairs and power scooters throughout the area that areramped. Toilet facilities are via the providers I mentioned earlier, did not use them so can not comment. Access is from either Castle Street, Rose Street that runs parallel with George Street and via Charlotte Square. As there is no traffic you can utilise the road areas, it‚Äôs busy but not congested. It is staffed by the same event company and they are particularly helpful.

We went to hear Sharon Van Etten last night - the venue was standing on the ground floor and open seating on the balcony, which is up 33 steps. No lift.  The ground floor is flat access from the street but there‚Äôs nothing to help you see over the standing crowd if you‚Äôre sitting down, as was mentioned in the other review.  Festival staff were polite but unable to help with access in any way.  I gave it two stars because I surprised myself with being able to climb and descend 33 steps!  I hope future work on the venue includes provision for people who can‚Äôt climb stairs or stand through an entire gig.

We have been here before and always enjoy our stay. We have 2 dogs one of which is my assistance dog. The lodge is very comfortable and spacious. The lodge sleeps 8 to 10 people and is dog friendly. There are also profiling beds in the lodge which helps me to sleep better. Lots to do in the local area. The seated exercise class on a Wednesday morning is great fun in the Paxton Centre.

Set in a modern building, the hotel offers accessible rooms, food and beverages, as well as a friendly welcome. Its location in the heart of the city made for easy access to everywhere we wanted to visit. 

A ten minute walk to the river side, five minutes to the main shopping area, and five minutes to the Victorian Market made for a great time.

US Capitol  is one of the most iconic buildings in Washington DC. I would say it‚Äôs a must see. Entrance was free. Once we got through security ( for prohibited üö´ items see https://www.visitthecapitol.gov/plan-visit/prohibited-items )‚Äôwe made our way to the tour (45 mins long). I would suggest that you pre-book your place on a tour on the Capitol Hill website to avoid queuing ( https://www.visitthecapitol.gov/plan-visit/book-tour-capitol). The tour was packed with information about the history of the building and the congress.
After the tour we spent 45 mins !!!!! queuing to go into the senate gallery ( https://www.visitthecapitol.gov/plan-visit/watching-congress-session). I am not sure it was worth the wait.
We then had a quick snack in the large cafeteria that had a selection of basic hot/cold/sweet and savoury food.
Overall I would say the building was extremely accessible and I would definitely recommend visiting it. More details about accessibility to follow.

The National Memorial Arboretum, not been in my chair before, I would hope they are geared up for me! As they deal with many veterans and amputees don't they.  Yes I was right and all was well.  First thing to do was go on the Land Train  that runs round the site.  This was good as there was a commentary on the memorials we passed, I managed to hear most of it too.  The best bit of it was I could stay in my chair as I was just wheeled aboard.
Following on from the train was to walked about a bit (you know what I mean) the paths are really smooth and wide, although there are some memorial which require off road skills.  At one point there were steps but a smooth slope was adjacent to it.  There are also plenty of benches for pushers to rest.  Not sure how I would get up to the memorial wall,  As it threatened rain and we went in for coffee and cake.  However whilst on the train I did see a wheelchair being pushed up a spiral path but it looked like hard work and I am not sure Mom would be up to that.  Before leaving I checked out the shop which was easy to negotiate and the disabled loo which was fine and one of the best layouts visited yet

Access into the entrance is on the level, and you reach the reception desk, but this has steps down into the booking in area of reception, but willing staff came to help us. Just across from reception is the beautifully decorated George‚Äôs Bar, and you really must go in and enjoy the views and a welcomed drink, but sadly, there are steps you have to go down to benefit the lounge area. You have a choice now, of sitting by the bar itself, which is on the level before the steps down into bar lounge, 
or you can go outside again, along to the ramp of the terrace patio, and back across to the doorway, with a pull handle, and get into the main lounge which is now all on the level for you. A bit of a nuisance if it‚Äôs raining, but it is such a lovely lounge.
If you now want to enjoy looking around the Abbey, or taking afternoon tea, or using the bathroom, you will need to go outside again, across the terrace and up the ramp and back to reception area, where the Abbey and all its holds is yours.  Do try to spend some time wandering along many corridors with amazing rooms to see, it‚Äôs on the level for you, so have a go, just encourage your carer to keep going, it‚Äôs a beautiful Abbey, so do not miss out.
Didn't use the accessible loo so can't make further comment on it other than it was at least located at a good position next to the access door.

There is inbuilt ramp to get it, the doorway is not especially wide so larger wheelchairs may struggle. There is a lowered counter to pay, it‚Äôs table service which is helpful, and the tables are a good height. One time I went and there weren‚Äôt any of the ‚Äònormal‚Äô tables and just a booth but the staff were helpful and said it was ok to get out of my chair and have it sitting in the isle so I could sit in the booth. It s quite a busy cafe so getting a table on weekends is hard if you don‚Äôt book.
All generally unclean, and of the porta cabin variety.  Disabled facilities, shared with baby change so queues, impatient people  a problem.  No disabled changing.

Such attention to detail was shown by all staff we met - and so helpful but not at all intrusive. After my 1st night, I mentioned that there was no reading light in my bedroom - I had an excellent contemporary lamp the following evening!
There is a small patch of rather rough ground next to the visitor centre which is labelled for disabled parking.
People were cooperative with deafness, using notepads and pens for communication.

To get in there is one glass door that opens inwards. Turn right and you will be seated by staff. When entering a chair was moved from a table instantly and everything was smooth. One star off just because of the door being heavy I could not open this independently.

I had such a great night here! The food was amazing, great service and zero accessibility issues, I just wish I got better photos! The atmosphere was relaxed, the smells were amazing, the service was really good. I can‚Äôt eat much and have a feeding tube, there was nothing I‚Äôd be able to eat from the starters so I asked for a main meal of chicken and roast potatoes as a starter- very small, no veg or salad etc, they provided this at half the normal price. I really appreciated the chef doing this, the plate still looked amazing and I felt like I was able to ‚Äòparticipate‚Äô more in dinner  with my friends.

Level access into shop with automatic doors. Seating available near till. Hearing loop sign spotted. Shelves were high. Didn't see a designated accessible till. Wheelchair accessible trolley available.

There are 3 parking spaces outside of the gym, they aren't disabled parking spaces but if you exit from the back of your vehicle it would be okay. The owner said to me if my beautician mentions to her that I am coming she will put a cone out so there is a space available for me.

I'm not from this area so I don't know much about the public transport but the beauticians is located on the main street of Invergowrie so I think there will be bus stops nearby.

The staff in the restaurant in particular were all charming and happy to assist with anything they could from moving a chair out of the way to make room for a wheelchair, to carrying the tray over to the table. They went out of their way to make sure we had anything we needed and I was deeply grateful to them.
National Trust volunteers provide buggy rides for the less able, but book in advance.
Could not be better, outside the front door and on smooth tarmac.

Access across the railway at Westerton Train Station used to be via a narrow pedestrian bridge making it very difficult for anyone with impaired mobility to access both platforms.

The old bridge was replaced in 2018 by a new wider bridge and lifts have been installed making it easier for all passengers to cross the railway to the opposite platform.
Very helpful staff that are ready to open doors and answer your questions with out any qualms.

All staff that I spoke to during my visit to Sleeperz were very friendly and helpful. Due to not staying over I didn‚Äôt have the usual enquiries that I do in other hotels. I did speak to the General Manager about the need for a hoist and he said he would look into it, which is always a positive thing.

There are 8 or 9 disabled bays outside the Cinema, however they are nearly always full and for a large complex with a bowling alley and numerous restaurants the proportion of disabled bays is not working.

Disabled loo clearly marked and staff showed where lifts and loo were when getting off the carriage, I say getting off but it was totally level access for the disabled seats. Very clean,roomy,with good rails.

Our first visit, everything thing was just right. Cottage with everything we needed including the hot tub :-)
Even the weather was kind to us. We shall certainly be going again. Thank you everyone at Brickhouse Cottages.
We came as pedestrians. Parking likely tricky given it's on a busy road but there are lots of buses running up North Bridge.
There are disabled toilets and it was easy to get there

It‚Äôs a compressed soil area, with wide paths, and a lot can be seen, but at New Fancy it‚Äôs not really disabled friendly, as too hilly, but worth going to see for a quick visit.
A short drive away you will arrive at Mallards Pike, a beauty spot, again with wide compressed soil parking area and paths. This site is a little more hilly than others, but you can cope. After paying ¬£2.00 for parking ticket, a number of walks can be taken, your carer should manage quite well for you. Seating is available to enjoy views,  but cafe will be closed over winter.

Disabled access is fantastic the security lane for disabled people is separate. They are lifts inside both Victoria station and Manchester arena that are easily accessible. Disabled viewing platforms are available in each block with security present to assist if needed. Singage Through the venue was clear.
Easily accessible location for wheelchair users
The staff member who answered the phone to me came straight down to give access. At every opportunity they offered help and support which is great.
Plenty of rails and room.
Good clean loo, situated in the bar. Red cord was tied up but otherwise very clean, good quality soap and handcream, very stylish.
There are large accessible toilets in the booking hall. Staff will help with directions as they are tucked away around a corner.
Friendly and showed us a map. I think we could have navigated the one room without the pre talk on how to see the exhibits.

The keypad entry has small keys and there is no raised line on the 5 for those with visual impairments. You can get a fob which makes things easier but they cost ¬£6. The door is electronic but it opens really quick so it hits the front of my chair. The water fountains are not at an accessible height and the sign for toilets points to the stairs not the lift. There is a lift to all floors but the doors are manual and you have to keep holding the button down to get it to work. There are no machines that can be used directly from a wheelchair other than free weights and majority of the machines are awkward transfers as well There is no braille signs. They do require those with access needs to have a Personal Evacuation Plan. There are help points with large print signs. The help point has braille label.
parking is tricky.there are buses which pick up some of the clients who use the facilities. on the whole,the disabled facilities are very good
The toilets are roomy, clean and easy to access.
Access through main doors and rear access to rooms.

Staff are excellent at physically helping if you want e.g. with carrying drinks, guiding a blind folk, operating lifts, reserving seats together in the cinema, if you come as a group, etc.
I'd describe the staff as helpful, cheerful, respectful. They are very disability aware and are well trained. The wheelchair space booking system on their computers seems to be very clunky - not the staff's fault.

This is the killer. The toilets are down a staircase below the stage. Absolute disaster for the disabled. There's a disabled loo in the locked church opposite & you might try George & Davis ice-cream over the road for a loo.
there is a disabled toilet next to the ticket office you have to ask staff for the key.
The station staff were all very helpful, the staff in the booking office particularly so.
Lift to all levels, Electric doors with low level push button

This is an old listed building however there is a small lift on the outside of the building for step free access and on the inside there are plenty lifts to take you throughout the building. There are a number of toilets and the staff were extremely helpful.
Disabled toilet on site access a little bit tight but  possible
Staff were very friendly and helpful.
Their is a car park within the venue, its on a major road just behind the Glasgow Fort

Inside the venue, I couldn't fault the access. My only gripe was the heavy double entrance doors for my hubbie to push me through. However the jolly and plentiful stewards were quick to react and help him.  Flooring is smooth to wheel on.  All wheelchair spaces were at entrance level as were the loos and food/drink outlets (which were great as well). I got a fantastic view - the row in front was sufficiently low as not to impede my view even when they stood up.  Whole track is easy to see.
Spacious and very well-equipped, with a wide door. Easy to get to from the dining areas.
Staff were all friendly, very welcoming & helpful.
The staff were helpful and informative, and opened more suitable ways in for me on my scooter when things got a bit tight around the entrance/shop area.
Very good apart from the havy fire doors
There are disabled parking spaces from the side entrance to the station. Low-level and high level trains can be accessed via a ramp which can be booked with Scotrail Passenger Assistance.
We have always found the staff friendly and efficient.
I took the wheelchair taxi, but public buses will stop here, and large car park with several dedicated accessible spaces

Assist staff are excellent. They have set area's for wheelchairs, stand alone  chairs if you need more room for whatever reason. Access to a disabled toilet. The member of staff helping me checked on me regularly to make sure I was comfortable, was there anything she could get me etc. I was treated very well and it made the whole evening a very enjoyable experience. There is a number to phone to arrange and more information on their website about what is available.

North Berwick is notorious for lack of parking. You will have to park on street parking. You will have to park in the main car park opposite the ship inn  there are blue badge spaces. Walk on to the street turn right and signals is one hundred meters .

The staff couldn't have been more friendly and helpful and really went the extra mile to help me out despite my 'special needs' (!), for instance bringing me out a chair while I was waiting in the queue. They also replied to my Facebook queries about accessibility very quickly with really useful information, and an unprompted offer to reserve me a table for the gig. Lovely people.
Many buses serve this store so it's easy to get here, there are very large car parks too so it won't be a problem getting a space here.

I met up with some friends for coffee at the lounge bar of the DoubleTree Hilton hotel in Edinburgh city centre. This venue has the Neatebox app Welcome installed so I was able to let them know in advance that I was coming and what assistance requirements I need. As soon as I arrived I was greeted at the entrance by Ricardo who guided me through to the lounge bar where I met up with friends for a coffee and blether.

level access , automatic doors , wide foyer , no doors into the public areas , including the restaurant. Ample lifts with good space inside so no problems for wheel chairs getting to all floors.
The accessible bedroom I stayed in had a working automatic door which enabled easy departure from the room and unlike most hotels with automatic doors , the mechanism was in good working order. The only issue was that the door was only automatic from inside the room , not on entry and overcoming the inertia  to push the door open was difficult. Getting out was a breeze
Roomy entrance to bathroom and plenty of space for transfers both in bathroom and bedroom.
There is an accessible loo near the cafe and another at the bird of prey centre, both of which are really spacious with plenty of grab rails.
Great loo - very spacious!
Parking was near the facility and easy to use, there were spaces
Lots of disabled parking in front of the building
Complete step free access throughout.
No specific wheelchair parking and the car park was a bit bumpy and pot holey.
Staff raced out with a ramp which gave access to all restaurant

Long gently sloping ramp to entrance but uneven slabs making progress difficult for wheelchair. Inside lobby wheelchair lift to raise approx 3 feet to Restaurant. Assisted by reception staff whether I wanted it or not. When up to restaurant level gate opened and switch/lock mechanism fell off. When challenged, staff said it wasn't actually "broken" it had "just fallen off" and it had been like that for some time. It was then pushed back into place to prove that! It fell off again when going back down later.
Floors in restaurant flat but not level (it is a historic building).
There were accessible toilets which were very well located.
We drove in our car. The website details where the on road blue badge parking is and it is quite close to venue. Not lots of blue badges spaces but we got parked easily.
Friendly staff.

From the train to the station concourse is fairly straigforward once you locate the lift. It's tucked away at the end of the platform along its own corridor. The lift itself is large and has plenty of turning space. Once on ground level there's a clearly marked route to the barriers where one is wide enough for wheelchair access. One route out of the station from the Jubilee Line is level.
We used the jubilee line so it was easy to get to this station. Not sure what the access is like for for the district & circle lines?

Lots of space in the Loo plenty of room to maneuver a powered wheelchair. Everything in the one room a wash hand basin, toilet, shower and a bath also a commode shower chair. Still room for a power-chair and a portable hoist if needed. Photos on the website will show the layout of the room. A standard toilet with drop-down bars, also a toilet raiser so all sizes catered for with the commode shower chair going over the toilet.

Signage was minimal, there was no seating to rest on, from the parking to the venue.  Access to the food festival was off the main path, onto and then across the grass which was muddy in places.  Difficult with a walking frame.  No matting to make it accessible for difficult at best. Site of the festival itself is on a slope and very muddy, again with no matting in the area's of heavy footfall.
Good sized accessible toilet.
Big toliets with grab rails wet rooms in disabled rooms with seat
Everyone we meet during our time in the village were doing the work voluntary were very helpful and wanted to tell you about the village etc
We were met by Kim on arrival who was extremely friendly and helpful.  All staff we met during our stay were exceptional -a real asset.
Wheelchairs could get into the castle but dont expect to get very far once in. If your able to walk, you will probably have a good time.
Always friendly and polite.
Friendly and helpful. One staff member saw us heading for the accessible toilet and rushed across to open the doors for us.

Flat surface and level access entrance into the store. There is a revolving door with a wheelchair button, which I think slows down the turning of the door. I've never had to do this as the door doesn't revolve very fast anyway. There is also a wheelchair accessible door on the left which has a large push button to automatically open the door.

There is a large lift to take you up to the showroom, but there is also a wide door to take you through to the markethall if you don't want to go through the showroom. Lots of space to move around.

There's plenty of disabled parking close to the entrance and there is no height restriction meaning that large WAVs and Minibuses can use it too, which is handy as it is situated next to the Eastgate Shopping Centre but it's worth noting that there is a 3 hour maximum time limit.
Excellent in every way: good lifts (when they're working, which is usually), good staff, easy access all areas.

Level access, automatic electric doors.

Wheelchair accessible trolleys are located inside. Mobility scooters & manual wheelchairs available.  They also have the small metal baskets.

Hearing loops were available according to signs. 

I didn't see any designated accessible tills. Not much space at scan and go tills. 

The shelving and fridges/freezers were typical of supermarkets and difficult to access. The scales for fruit and veg was really high. 

No music but they do have a tannoy system.

The lift to up stairs is at back of store inside the Argos.
There was a proper disabled toilet at the hovercraft report on the Isle of Wight
Staff are always very friendly in Mimi's and will offer you a very warm welcome.
There was some lovely scenery on the walk.
Despite the obvious limitations of an old building, access was quite straightforward and staff were lovely.  My transfer seat had a great view of the stage.

Level and very smooth access, plenty of shops, disabled toilets, lifts. Always clean.  Can be  a little busy at weekends. Plenty of places to eat. Feels safe to shop. Long opening hours. Would recommend.
Really friendly and helpful. Thanks!

Chemist treatment room is too small for wheelchair.

Didn't see any manual wheelchairs or accessible trolleys.
In general staff are helpful and pleasant.

Clear signposting
Flat access
Automatic doors
Plenty of room for wheelchairs to manoevere in reception and clinical areas
Wheelchair height area at reception desk
Facilities for hearing impaired clients
Walking distance not too far for mobility impaired, but wheelchairs to assist available just inside entrance,
 seating close to entrance, and reasonable height seating all with arm rests
Dedicated safe play area for children next to reception with full  observation , and key code to access area

Four star water front hotel opposite Torquay railway station.  Overall in the communal areas there is very good accessibility ramps, accessible public spaces and accessible toilet on ground floor, 2 lifts. The hotel has 132 rooms and their website states "The Grand has one bedroom with fully-equipped wet room, fitted with grab rails around the bathroom and it is situated on the ground floor.  A shower stool can be provided for use in this room."
Nearest tube is Greenwich

This was very problematic. Firstly the accessible toilet is not sign posted. It is in a corridor behind a door marked staff only. One of my own colleague told me off for going into an area marked staff only, see photo. When I went through this door I found that a trolley was blocking the accessible toilet. This happened twice during my stay. When I went into the toilet for the first time there was a stair climber wheelchair, which took up most of the space in the toilet, I was told this was there as it had been used the day before. I explained that the accessible toilet should not be used as a store room.  This was removed before my second loo break. The toilet had grab rails and was clean. The emergency cord didn't reach to the ground.
The staff were very friendly and helpful. They gave us the closest table which was easy to use, they took chairs away without needing instructed. Good experience!

This museum is located in the old White Star Line building in Cobh (formerly Queenstown), which is where people would have bought their tickets for a journey on the company's liners. Cobh/Queenstown was the Titanic's last stop before the ship came to grief in the mid-Atlantic, and the museum focuses particularly on the Irish passengers who boarded there. At the beginning, you are given a 'boarding pass' with one of the real Queenstown passengers' names on it, and after you have worked your way through the various video presentations, recreations of Titanic cabins and displays of artefacts, you find out whether the passenger on your boarding pass survived the sinking.

As a wheelchair/scooter using visitor, I felt able to join in with all parts of the experience at the museum. There's a wheelchair lift to get into the building which you can operate yourself (unlike some places where you have to send in a person who can climb stairs to ask for help, which isn't really proper access). When you get inside, it's sometimes a little tight around the corners, but given the importance of housing the museum in the historic setting of the White Star Line museum, I felt that a good job had been done in making the access as good as possible.

You can walk around two of the pond areas at Monikie and both pathways are layered with grass. The pathways vary in width as you walk around and in certain areas there are stones within the ground that can cause the pathway to be quite bumpy. There is a gradient hill at either side of the pathway so it might be difficult for wheelchair users that aren‚Äôt very confident with their driving. When I walk past the ponds I always feel more comfortable going to the left as I feel that pathway is better, and it‚Äôs a shorter walk for the colder days.

Before or after your walk, there are two grassy areas to enjoy a sit down, picnic or BBQ. These are all flat areas and very spacious. If your lucky you might even be joined by the ducks that live in Monikie Country Park.

The ground in the childrens play parks is mainly covered in bark which can be quite difficult for wheelchair users to drive on. There is a pathway going around the pay equipment but, you can‚Äôt get close to any of it. Between the two play parks at Monikie there is a small wooden bridge to go over which I feel would be hard to drive on as there are wooden ridges at the start and end of the bridge. I just feel the combination of driving on a gradient and over the ridges would be difficult.

There is also a caf√©/restaurant on the grounds of Monikie Country Park called ‚Ä¶, which I will review separately another time.

On the University of Leeds campus just outside the city centre, in the Student's Union, Old Bar is a great accessible pub!

Obviously full of students, but lecturers and visitors too, Old Bar has a great atmosphere whenever you go. 
They have a wide range of food and drinks, with a varied menu that caters for vegetarians, vegans, lactose and gluten intolerances. 

There is a pool table and they have various TV screens that show the news or sports, with additional screens that come down to project bigger matches too. They have a pub quiz every Thursday, with other events such as gigs every so often. 
This does mean that it can be quite busy on Fridays and Saturdays, and the noise levels may be problematic for some people. 

There is a lift down to Old Bar as well as step free access around the side. There is an accessible toilet as well as gender neutral toilets if required.

Excellent modern accommodation finished to the highest of standards, with wonderful views over the open country side. Warm welcome and great full English breakfast. Would have stayed longer but no vacancy. No hesitation in recommending, whether able bodied or not.
Plenty of disabled parking with level access to main entrance.  Automatic doors

The bathroom was very disappointing and clearly a token effort.  I knew before we arrived there was going to be a bath instead of a shower.  Not great but I was only staying 1 night.  The toilet was extremely low (even my dad commented how low it was), thankfully I had asked for the height when booking and brought my own seat riser (they don‚Äôt supply such a thing), even with that it was hard work.  The hand rails were badly located, the drop down one even when down was too far back to be of use.

The sink was lower down, but as it was boxed in there was no room for knees underneath.  They had also opted for two taps instead of a mixer one. Such a scolding issue.

Unfortunately they had decided not to put a carpet bar on, so the join between the bathroom tiles and room carpet had a raw edge that I got my foot caught in each time.

The floor files also got very slippy when wet, I couldn‚Äôt get off the toilet when we first arrived as my feet kept sliding. 

There was no disabled toilet upstairs at the function suite as no access.  However there was one in the foyer of the hotel, but I never used it.

All staff that I encountered during my visit were very friendly and helpful. They made sure I knew which areas weren‚Äôt accessible and they always greeted you when you walked past them during the walk.

The only issue I had, and I don‚Äôt even know if you can count this as staff, but I struggled to get in touch with the organisers of the event by multiple emails to get my free carer ticket. Their office was only open I think 3 days during the week and I had to eventually phone them on the day I was attending the event and it got sorted. But it was very stressful as up until the day I didn‚Äôt know if I would be able to go.

Staff where friendly and helpful.
Though I was with my carer the staff in the caf√© where happy to get items for me in the caf√©.
Caf√© staff where also helpful when I asked about allergies.
Around there store however there was no staff around to help e.g. to point out how inaccessible the layout of the shop was or to ask to help find items.
Very helpful and friendly. Nothing too much trouble
bus stops nearby
Toilet was huge, had a hoist, changing bed and height adjustable sink. Toilet flush wasnt great. Lots of space for a carer- you could fit a whole family in there!

I wouldn't call it accessible, but they've done what they can - a dozen or so steps down, then a 90 degree turn and a few more steps down to the door to the loos (and another area with further tables).

On the way down the stairs you can check out some of the goods for sale - i picked up a lovely Moroccan bowl.

Stairs are metal with a textured surface which helps your feet grip. Chunky banister right down - poss. both sides? Definitely on left though.

The accessible loo itself had plenty of room for me - although of course I'd had to leave the scooter upstairs!
Everyone we met on the bus journeys was helpful and friendly.
Parking next to disabled accommodation
Paved path to barn. No steps. Low threshold that wheelchair could be taken over. Space to move about in main area and surfaces made moving easy (in a wheelchair).

It was easy to wheel into the park from the street. The main paths are hard surfaced and fairly level; as well as being in good condition. It was fairly easy to wheel on to the grass areas and have a look around.

There are dedicated areas within the park such as the children's play area and the football area.
No designated car park but you can park on the street outside the cafe and there are many buses stopping nearby.

Red cord had been replaced with string and had been knotted so it could not reach the ground. Two bins by the entrance. Was pretty dirty even for festival standards :) Ridiculous signage - door was covered with flyers so you could barely make out where it is.
Friendly and extremely helpful.
All the equipment you could need supplied and thoughtfully laid out shower room and toilets
Good size toilet access could be better but right across from Costa in shopping centire is an excellent rader key toilet good size good access very pleased.
All of the staff we dealt with were very pleasant, helpful and willing.
Their is a disabiled toilet just outside of the main room what is really good

Excellent! All areas accessible and I could see everything I wanted. There are one or two tanks that you can actually climb into but I couldn't get into those but all the others were laid out with plenty of room to wheel around them. 
We didn't go outside on our visit due to the weather so can't comment on the accessibility of the outside unfortunately.

You enter the shop through level access however the entrance door is pretty tight but once you are past the entrance then the shop has normal garden centre products and a lovely wee coffee which I would definitely recommend.
Access on one level if entering from the main street, to access the bar would need to use entrance on Lochrin Place as a few steps up from the bar from the main entrance.

We got their via DLR and Underground from Greenwich. Got off at South Kensington and walked for about seven minutes through the covered walkway and through the museums underground entrance. The exhibition was about a three minute walk away.
Managed to get round the garden but that was all.

There are 22 reserved parking spaces for disabled customers.

There is free use of wheelchairs offered for the period of your duration at the shopping centre. Mobility scooters are also available, as the centre works in partnership with Travel Extra Mobility Service. For more information about the hiring, there is information on the website https://www.ststephens-hull.com/
Staff are great. They go out of their way to ensure you have a great day.

It‚Äôs all woodland, so expect a little huffing and puffing, but on a dry day, you may get around quite easily, it depends on the strength of your carer. We did not see any benches for a rest, so bear this in mind as to the distance you want carer to push.

Space is provided adjacent to the toilet in the cabin for easy transfer from wheelchair. However, as someone over 6 foot tall, the hand rails are a bit low and there is no high level support for someone standing upright.

(There are other accessible toilets around the ferry, however I've never needed to try them ...)

I didnt find any accessible toilets. On the ground floor there are regular toilets. 

In my room although there was no toilet grab rail I was able to easily use the vanity unit to help me up.
Flat access throughout accommodation including onto large terrace from 2 patio doors
As mentioned, the disabled are treated like royalty in this cruise terminal and nothing is too much for the superb staff to handle.

Disabled access to the tents was good but not sure about any of the rides as i didn't go on any.Make sure you get a table or you can't buy any food or drink ,areas set aside for wheelchair users but they get busy early.
Across the road from Haymarket Station and on several bus routes.

There was a space marked with a Blue Badge symbol near the archway that leads to the hotel and there is ample parking generally. The car park was gravel which could have been a problem, but we were able to park near enough to the pathway to be able to get straight onto it.

Vikingar is my local lesuire centre. There are swimming and gym facilities available I have recently been attending a low circuit fitness class which is mostly seated. Staff are very helpful and will work with you on a fitness programme that suits your needs There are accessible changing rooms and the pool can be accessed using a hoist.
We stayed in Pinder cottage, though Hoe Grange has a range of cottages with different levels of access. Not only is there excellent access but also equipment to borrow if needed.
Extremely attentive and efficient, esp with a noisy lively group
There are lifts and several bathrooms specifically designed for people with physical disabilities, making it a comfortable environment.
Lovely welcome from every volunteer that we encountered, offers of help without needing to ask.

We accessed the beach via a path accessed around the side of the houses beside the lighthouse and carpark.
No signage, it was a local resident who approached me and kindly showed me how to access the path, which he said had recently been resurfaced
Path not tarmac, and a bit bumpy  and uneven in places.
Level access to picnic area
Seating at picnic area

There is one accessible toilet on the first floor located next to the lifts. there is room for a carer to assist in this area if required. Access is via 2 doors. 
There was a red cord in this toilet but was tied up Red Cord card left
All the staff were very helpful and knowledgeable. The role-play element of the main tour was particularly engaging.
The parking was limited. There was a car park around side too. The accessible bays appear wider but aren't very well marked.
